Award.AwardTitle: Dispersion engineering using leaky-mode resonant photonic lattices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project objective: The objective of this project is to conduct theoretical and experimental research on the dispersion properties of nanostructured resonance elements. Fundamentally new types of dispersive devices using leaky-mode resonance effects in subwavelength photonic lattices will be designed, fabricated, and tested.

Intellectual merit: This project charts new directions in photonic device technology based on nanostructured subwavelength elements. The proposed devices are unexploited in slow-light engineering. This project will define their applicability. Computations show that leaky-mode resonance devices compare favorably with leading concepts in the field. Although based on totally different fundamentals, in structure and device density, the proposed concept is similar to photonic-crystal based micro-resonator chips whose fabrication is particularly challenging. It appears that the proposed leaky-mode resonance delay lines can be fabricated more directly. Additionally, the elements show flat transmission spectra across useful bands. Detailed comparison requires fabrication and testing of prototype devices. As very little is currently known about these effects in the context of slow light, this project constitutes basic research.

Broader impact: If the research verifies the practicality of these concepts, this work can have a major impact in promoting new device technology. Very compact optical delay lines, signal buffers in all-optical communication systems, and light-storage elements would become feasible. Moreover, this project is aligned with a broad plan to develop research and education in photonic nanostructures at the University of Texas at Arlington. It will strengthen research in photonic crystals and integrated photonic circuits and support efforts in building nanofabrication methods and infrastructure. With the principal investigator?s recent appointment to the Texas Instruments Distinguished University Chair in Nanoelectronics, major funding for equipment and facilities was provided. This project, which seeks mainly student salary support, would thus enhance the use of new, modern facilities. Therefore, the proposed project provides excellent analytical and experimental experience for both graduate and undergraduate students. There is special focus on recruiting female students as well as students belonging to populations that are underrepresented in science and engineering and converting them into new graduate students. In addition, the principal investigator is Chief Technical Officer of Resonant Sensors Incorporated, a start-up company developing new sensor technology. As part of his duties under the Texas Instruments Chair, he will teach a yearly course on entrepreneurship and business, open to all undergraduate and graduate students, to stimulate innovation and technology transfer. The results of this research will be widely disseminated in journals and conferences. As there is currently a heavy worldwide emphasis on the study of periodic layers and lattices, new publications and results, illustrating the interesting effects and applications realized in the leaky-mode regime, might stimulate additional research and technological progress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Rayleigh anomaly is a famous phenomenon in optical physics but is widely regarded as substantially useless. This prominent effect arises on spatially-periodic surfaces illuminated by incident electromagnetic waves including light waves. The Rayleigh anomaly refers to the appearance or disappearance of diffracted spectral waves under a variation of the input light frequency or angle. At the transition point between propagating and evanescent (i.e. vanished) diffracted light waves, characteristic kinks appear in the spectra. This spectral disturbance is a nuisance, for example, to the spectroscopist using diffraction gratings to obtain useful information about atomic absorption processes in a medium under study. We note that diffraction gratings are key components in optical spectrum analyzers in worldwide use today; thus all these instruments are susceptible to the Rayleigh anomaly. Even though this effect has been known for over 100 years, no practical application has been found. We present here a potentially beneficial application that the Rayleigh anomaly enables. We have analyzed the device in detail with rigorous numerical methods and also fabricated an initial working prototype. Thus, we have managed to turn a detrimental effect into a positive enabling attribute!

            Accordingly, to explain this further, we have invented a new class of optical devices that we call Rayleigh reflectors. The reflector provides extremely sharp angular spectra with 100% reflectance across wide angular extents. Enabling the device is a rapid, thus far unknown, high-efficiency transition from an evanescent to a propagating first-order substrate wave occurring at the Rayleigh angle. A nanolayer with high refractive index that is located adjacent to the substrate is seen to critically affect the resulting spectra. Away from the Rayleigh anomaly, the device is a basic guided-mode resonance high reflector. Hence, this new device connects the fundamental concepts of guided-mode resonance and the Rayleigh anomaly with interesting possible applications including new filters and couplers.

            Figure 1 schematically illustrates the model of the device. The grating layer is etched partially into a silicon film, generally leaving a sublayer with controllable thickness next to the substrate. Figure 2 shows the angular spectrum of the device. The extremely sharp transitions at the Rayleigh angle shape the response to yield 100% reflectance across a sharp, rectangular angular band with an extraordinarily rapid transition at the filter edges as seen in the figure.  Figure 3 provides a reflectance map of a representative Rayleigh reflector made in silicon-on-glass. The dashed line marks the location of the Rayleigh anomaly. A sharp angular corridor appears near wavelength of 2.1 mm.

            Many applications of this device class can be envisioned. For example, as the input wave is converted to a high-efficiency substrate wave propagating at high angles and thus contained in the substrate, applications as couplers may be feasible. Another use might be in edge illumination of holograms or other display elements. The general field of optical interconnects for signal propagation and detection within a substrate layer may be enriched by these concepts. The devices may find use in optical communications and integrated silicon photonics.
